stem: The nurse is interpreting fetal heart rate (FHR) monitor strips. Match each FHR pattern with its most likely cause and corresponding intervention.

rows.text: Late Decelerations (Uniform shape, begins after contraction peak).
Variable Decelerations (Abrupt U, V, or W shape).

columns.text: Cause: Head Compression; Action: Continue to Monitor
Cause: Cord Compression; Action: Position Change
Cause: Uteroplacental Insufficiency; Action: Stop Pitocin, IV Bolus, Left Side
Cause: Fetal Well-being; Action: Document findings

rationale.correct: FHR patterns reflect fetal oxygenation and stress. (r1) Early decels are a normal reflex to head pressure in the birth canal. (r2) Late decels are 'ominous' and indicate the placenta isn't delivering enough oxygen. (r3) Variables are caused by cord issues. (r4) Accels are a reassuring sign of an intact neurological system.
rationale.incorrect: Early decelerations do not require intrauterine resuscitation; they are benign.
clinicalPearls: Remember 'VEAL CHOP' for easy matching of patterns to causes.

questionTrap.howToOvercome: If you see a 'Late' deceleration, do not just 'monitor.' You MUST take action (Stop Oxytocin, Position Left, Oxygen, Fluids).

reviewUnits.heading: Electronic Fetal Monitoring (EFM)
reviewUnits.body: Nurses must interpret Category I (Normal), II (Indeterminate), and III (Abnormal) strips. Category III strips (Absent variability with late decels) require immediate delivery preparations.
reviewUnits.source: ACOG: Fetal Heart Rate Monitoring Standards
